question: When a tertiary alcohol A (<katex>$C_{4}H_{10}O$</katex>) reacts with 20% <katex>$H_{3}PO_{4}$</katex> at 358 K, it gives a compound 'B' (<katex>$C_{4}H_{8}$</katex>) as a major product. The IUPAC name of the compound 'B' is:
explanation: The tertiary alcohol with formula <katex>$C_4H_{10}O$</katex> is tert-butyl alcohol (2-methylpropan-2-ol). Dehydration gives 2-methylpropene (Isobutylene) as the product.
